chapter.title: &QMTest; Core Implementation
chapter.para: This chapter describes the Python implementation of the core QMTest components. For some components, many implementations are envisioned; the requirements for these implementations are given.

section.title: Test class implementations
section.para: Each QMTest test class is implemented as a Python class. Though QMTest does not recognize any notion of test class inheritance, this may be produced in effect via Python class inheritance.

A test class should have the following members:
An initialization method (__init__), that is used to instantiate test instances. Test instances are Python instances of the Python class corresponding to the test class. The parameters of the __init__ method are the test class parameters. All parameters must be named; positional parameters are not allowed. A final ** parameter is allowed.
If a new test class is created via inheritance from a previous test class, the derived __init__ is expected to invoke the base class __init__, passing unused parameters.
An is_valid method. This method takes a Configuration object and returns as boolean whether the particular test instance is appropriate to run on that configuration.
A run method. The run method is passed the same configuration that was previously validated by the same test instance's is_valid method.
After this point, we will use the term test to refer to the corresponding Python class sometimes, when there is no ambiguity.

Instantiating a test instance requires locating and instantiating test class. This is done via these two methods:
The test class is located in the Python execution environment in the usual way, using the PYTHONPATH mechanism.
If the class has not been found, the test is asked to locate the test class. The test database is provided with the name of the test class and also with the test identifier being instantiated. (This allows the test database to handle relative paths in its conceptual tree, between the test id and the test class.)

section.title: Test records
section.para: Test records are represented by instances of the class QMTest.TestRecord. This class has the following members:
Note that test record objects are not polymorphic, regardless of the test class of the test.

Test records are the representation of tests that are stored in and returned by test databases. Most test database implementations will externalize test records to a persistent store. The preferred text-based format for doing this is XML.

An XML DTD for storing tests can be quite simple. Arguments are stored as CDATA, and are evaluated as Python expressions or treated as text literals. Below is the canonical DTD for storing test records.
<!ELEMENT test ( class, ( argument | category | prerequisite | preaction | postaction )* ) >
<!ELEMENT class (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT argument (#PCDATA)> <!ATTLIST argument name CDATA #REQUIRED type ( expression | text ) #IMPLIED >
<!ELEMENT category (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT prerequisite (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT preaction (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT postaction (#PCDATA)>

For example, a test record might be stored like this:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <QMTest.test> <class>compile_link_run</class> <argument name="input" type="text"> <![CDATA[ int main () { volatile int x = 2; return x - 2; } ]]> </argument> <argument name="flags">'-O%d -fpic' % get_optimization_level ()</argument> <category>C</category> <category>back end</category> <category>PIC</category> <category>optimization</category> <prerequisite>torture.link.test123</prerequisite> </QMTest.test>

section.title: Test instances
section.para: A test instance is an instance of a test classes. For a test to be run, a test instance must be created. To do this, the test class is first obtained from the test class name stored in the test record. The test arguments are extracted from the test record and evaluated in the test-time execution context. The results are passed to the initialization function of the test class to create the instance. To run the test, the instance's run method is invoked.
